sec.div: Methane emissions from enteric fermentation of ruminants
sec.p:
Methane emission from enteric fermentation for country i in year j ( F CH4-ruminant, i,j ) is calculated using Eq. ( 15) adapted from IPCC Tier 2 algorithms (ref.
13 , Vol. 4, Chapter 10, Eqn 10.21):
15
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$F_{{\mathrm{CH4 - ruminant}},i,j} = \frac{{\mathop {\sum }\nolimits GE_{{\mathrm{feed}},i,j} \times Y_{{\mathrm{m,feed}}}}}{{E_{{\mathrm{CH4}}} \times 10^9}}$$\end{document}
F
CH4-ruminant , i , j
=
∑ G
E
feed , i , j
×
Y
m,feed
E
CH4
× 1
0
9
where GE ruminant ,i,j (in MJ) is the annual gross energy intake by ruminants in country i in year j; E CH4 is the energy content of methane with value of 55.65 MJ (kg CH 4) −1; Y m,feed is the methane conversion factor expressed as the percent of gross energy in feed converted to methane; and 10 9 is to convert the unit of methane emission from kg to Tg (i.e., 10 12 g). In this study, Y m = 6.5% ± 1.0% (the ± values represent the 95% confidence interval range) is used to represent wide-spread ruminant fed diets for cattle and mature sheep following IPCC guidelines
13 (Vol. 4, Chapter 10, Tables 10.12 and 10.13), given the fact that globally, only little cattle in some developed countries is feedlot cattle with feed diets contain 90% or more concentrates. GE feed ,i,j is calculated as the gross energy content of different ruminant feeds (concentrates, grasses and other feeds):
16
\documentclass[12pt]{minimal} \usepackage{amsmath} \usepackage{wasysym} \usepackage{amsfonts} \usepackage{amssymb} \usepackage{amsbsy} \usepackage{mathrsfs} \usepackage{upgreek} \setlength{\oddsidemargin}{-69pt} \begin{document}$$GE_{{\mathrm{feed}},i,j} = Q_{{\mathrm{feed}},i,j} \times E_{{\mathrm{GE - feed}}}$$\end{document}
